runs.text: Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Discuss that the illustration shows a stump. Explain that a stump is what is left in the ground when a tree is chopped down.
Have students find the stump in the picture.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
benefit
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define: A
benefit
is anything that helps someone or does good for something.
Example: A stump can be a
benefit
for chipmunks. They can make their home there.
Ask: What is something that is a
benefit
to you? Tell your partner about it.
Read
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what they do to the big elm tree. (chop)
How does a rotten stump benefit, or help, animals? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why is Mom impressed with Beth?
Where would you most likely see a rotten stump? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Discuss that a pill bug is a kind of animal called a crustacean. These animals have two antennae, or feelers, two eyes, lots of legs, and a hard shell but no bones. Have students find the pill bug in the picture.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
relatives
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define:
Relatives
belong to the same family or group and have shared qualities.
Example: Lions and tigers are
relatives
because they are both in the cat family.
Ask: Who are some of your
relatives
? How are they related or connected to you? Tell your partner about it.
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what pill bugs use to breathe. (gills)
Why do the shrimp say that pill bugs are their relatives or cousins? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why might pill bugs need to protect themselves?
Have you ever seen a pill bug or another crustacean? Where did you see it?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Focus on Target Phonics Skill
Have students circle words with short
a
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner. Then ask them to draw a box around each word with short
e
and repeat the activity.
Write
Have students write a sentence using the word
fish
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss Phrasing
Discuss how to chunk the text into meaningful parts in order to read it. Point out the words in the first sentence that go together and can be chunked:
The grass/is wet.

Explain that fluent readers read each chunk as a phrase, pausing briefly between the chunks. Model how to use chunking to read the first sentence aloud. Have students echo read the sentence replicating your phrasing.
Explain
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle has a tricky question asked with a series of hints and an answer.
Read

For the first reading, have students read the question while you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the riddles. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingsone asks the question, while the other answers it.
Prompt

Prompt students to find all the words in the riddles with short vowel spellings and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Offer Phonics Supports
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Offer High-Frequency Word Supports
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the
Read/Build/Write
routine.
Read Aloud
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about an animal called a sloth. It lives in the rain forest, a thick jungle that gets lots of rain.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
behavior
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define:
Behavior
means the typical actions of a person or an animal.
Example: It is interesting to watch the
behavior
of an animal in its home.
Ask: What are some examples of a dog or cats
behavior
? Tell your partner about it.
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names a slow-moving animal that lives in the branches of the rain forest. (sloth)
What are some examples of a sloths behavior, or actions? Find some sentences that answer the question.
What are some reasons that a sloth spends most of its time in a tree?
Think of an animal that you know a lot about. How is it like a sloth? How is it different?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read them.
Focus on Target Phonics Skill

Have students circle words with short vowels. Have them point to and read those words to a partner. Then ask them to draw a box around each word with a consonant blend or digraph and repeat the activity.
Write
Have students write a sentence using the word
lunch
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss Sentence Structure
Discuss the different end punctuation for line 1 (period), line 2 (period, exclamation mark) and line 4 (question mark).
Model how to change intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement).
Have students echo-read the sentences replicating your intonation.
Explain

Read the title. Explain this text gives a description and a map of a sanctuary, or safe place, for sloths. The author included a map to show where different areas in the sanctuary are located. It is often easier for a reader to use a map to see where places are than to read a description.
Read
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the map.
Prompt
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the map.
Introduce

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a fable about two frogs. Remind them that a fable is a story that teaches a lesson.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
consequence
using the
Define/ Example /Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define: A
consequence
is the result of an action.
Example: A
consequence
of eating too much is a stomach ache.
Ask: Why should you think about the
consequences
of an action before you do it?
Read
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find a word that describes the wet place where the frogs lived. (pond)
What might have been a consequence, or result, if the frogs had jumped into the well? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What do frogs need in any place that they live? How do you know?
Why is Look before you leapa good lesson for you?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is an interview with a park ranger. It has a question and answer format. The interviewer, Grace, asks a question, and Ranger Diaz answers it.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
protect
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define:
Protect
means to keep safe.
Example: Sunscreen will
protect
your skin from sunburns.
Ask: What are some things that
protect
us from harm?
Read
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find a word that means what someone does for work. (job)
How does Ranger Diaz help protect, or keep safe, both people and black bears? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How does Ranger Diaz feel about his job? How do you know?
Would you like to visit Great Smoky Mountains National Park? Why or why not?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
